Title.evidence: This study aimed to assess the impact of common cardiovascular comorbidities on echocardiographic evaluation of aortic stenosis (AS) in a hospital setting.

Trial_Design.evidence: We retrospectively analyzed medical records of 234 hospitalized patients with moderate to severe AS, excluding those with acute myocardial infarction, prior valvular surgery, and congenital heart defects.

Participants.evidence: We retrospectively analyzed medical records of 234 hospitalized patients with moderate to severe AS, excluding those with acute myocardial infarction, prior valvular surgery, and congenital heart defects.

Objective.evidence: This study aimed to assess the impact of common cardiovascular comorbidities on echocardiographic evaluation of aortic stenosis (AS) in a hospital setting.

Method_Outcome.evidence: The primary outcome was the alteration in echocardiographic parameters due to comorbidities, measured within one month of admission.

Number_Analysed.evidence: Among the 234 patients (median age 76, 47.4% female), 85.0% had severe AS.

Result_Outcome.evidence: AF was associated with lower aortic valve mean pressure gradient (AVGmean, p = 0.001), peak velocity (Vmax, p < 0.001), and stroke volume (SV, p = 0.01), and higher left atrial (LA) area (p < 0.001).
